div.head: Calvert's Carbolic Toilet Soap
div.p: It is pure throughout, fragrantly perfumed, emollient, and antisceptic, (10% crystal carbolic). It quickly removes dust and dirt, takes away the unpleasant effects of perspiration, and leaves instead a delicious feeling of thorough purification.

p.hi: Sold by local Chemists and Storekeepers.

div.p: Made by F.C. Calvert & Co., Manchester, Eng.

div.head: “AU DE ROUGE."

IN SPUN SILK at P.T. 20 per pair.
LISLE THREAD, in plain and lace open-work, in black, white, tan and usual shades, to suit boots worn in Egypt, from P.T. 5 per pair.
Every pair is marked “Au De Rouge" which is a guarantee that the Color is absolutely fast and stainless.

div.head: The Nile Flotilla Co., Ld.

div.head: THE NATIONAL HOTEL, Cairo
div.p: One of the finest and most up-to-date Hotels in the Metropolis. Situated in Sharia Soliman Pasha, the very centre of the healthiest and most fashionable quarter. Stands in its own grounds with garden and lawn tennis grounds at back. Over 350 rooms and 5 saloons. Magnificent salle à manger. Handsome covered promenade verandah, 80 yards long. Highest class cuisine, electric light throughout, and lifts. English comforts. Rooms and apartments at prices to suit everyone. For further particulars apply to GENERAL MANAGER, Cairo.

div.head: GRAND HOTEL KHARTOUM, SUDAN
div.p: First Class. Open all the year round.

Standing in a magnificent position in its own extensive grounds on the banks of the Blue Nile. Perfect climate, no mosquitoes, moder comfort, very homely. Concerts twice a week on the verandah of the Hotel.
For accommodation please write or wire beforehand to Manager

div.head: Direction der Disconto-Gesellschaft
div.p: Berlin - Bremen - Frankfurt a. M. - London.
Represented at Hamburg by the Norddeutsche Bank in Hamburg.
The bank transacts general banking business of every description and acts as representative of the following foreign banks:
Brasilianische Bank für Deutschland of Hamburg, with branches at Rio de Janeiro, Sao Paulo, Santos and Porto Alegre.
Bank für Chile und Deutschland of Hamburg, with branches at Valparaiso, Santiago, Concepcion, Temuco, Antofagasta, La Paz and Oruro.
Deutsch- Asiatische Bank of Shanghai, with branohes at Berlin, Calcutta, Hankow, Hongkong, Kobe, Peking, Tientsin, Tsinanfu, Tsingtau, Yokohama.
Banca Generala Romana of Bakarest, with branches at Braila, Crajeva and an Agency at Constantza.
Kreditna Banka (Banque de Credit) at Sofia
Damara- und Namaqua Handels-Gesellschaft, Banking Department, at Swakopmund, Windhuk and Lüderitzbucht (South West Africa).

minary study, and consequently the interests of the varion* corporations will , not be sufficiently taken intoXxrasideration. This is, however, quite erroneous. The Egyptian Government has always made a point of consulting the import and export trades of Alexandria before taking any measure that might jeopardise thfiir interests. We have no doubt bat that the Government will do so in the present case. As to the position of the Alexandria Municipality in this matter,, we need merely state that the only step that has up to now been taken has been the communication to that body of the project of the new branch of the Canal. This scheme was submitted to the Municipality a few months ago in order to be studied by the members of the Municipal Commission. It was carefully drawn up by the able engineering authority* of the Ports and Lighthouses-Administration, M. Malavel, who' may be called the originator of the idea of the now branch. - The project has not yet been brought officially to the cognizance of the members of the Municipal Commission. One of the first conditions that the Municipality was prepared to insist upon was that in no way should the free flow of the existing canal be impeded lest in any case the purity of the present intake of the Alexandria Water Company should vbe endangered by havtfig a stagnant body of water existing below the site of the intake. Since then the question- has remained in statu quo. The Government! has now1 to give a decision on the matter, and will then doubtless consult the Municipality in order to take its opinion as to the advisability of proceeding with the projeot. An regards the Irrigation Department, trie scheme for a new maritime canal has been brought'to the notice of the Inspector General of Irrigation for Lower Egypt, • but as yet no definite steps have been taken. A new branch does not offer any objection from the point of view of irrigation, as it does not entail the Irrigation Department’s giving any more water, which is the main consideration with that department.

The actual scheme is the construction of a new salt-water canal running at ses level from Gabbari to Nouxha, where it would step up to the canal level by means of locks. It is obvious that such a scheme has many advantages. It prevents the silting up al the harbour, will improve the railway comniunications, relieve the congestion on the Mahiuoudieh Canal, and improve the sanitary condition of the port During the last four years the number of boats passing through the Menoufieh head lock at ' the barrage has more than quadrupled and the number of boats passing through the tail lock of the Mahmou- dieh Canal shows a similar increase. In 1905 the number of boats passing Kafr Da war up and down stream was 30,438, and annually 20,500 boats ply on the Nquxha*Mii«et-el- Bassal reach. The congestion grows worse every day, and the construction of the new branch is imperative, for it is the only solution out of the difficulty. Alexandria is growing rapidly, and will inevitably become not only the great outlet tor Egypt's railway traffic, but tor the greater part of Africa. The Cape-to Cairo Railway scheme may yet be far from being a “fait accompli,” but there is sure to be a complete system of communications between North and South Africa by rail, river, and lake in a few years’ time, and the outlet for this traffic will be at Alexandria. The growth of the town westward 'will In a few years’ time lead to one uninterrupted mass of buildings stretchingJrora Gabbari to Mex and occupying every available site between sea and lake. Unless, therefore, a decision is arrived at soon the scheme will not be feasible without enormous extra cost for expropriations. At the present time the land- owners interested in the promotion of the project are prepared to cede to the Egyptian Government free of any charge, the land necessary for making the new branch and they are ready to construct the canal under the supervision of the Government. They •further offer to give facilities for connecting tie goods station at Gabbari through the Gabbari quarter with the new ways to the west Under such favourable conditions .the new maritime canal could easily be constructed, and it is to be hoped that the Government will not lose the opportunity, for soon, owing to the rise in the value of the land consequence on the development of the ffity westward, the canal will never have a chance to be made without very great expense.
